components.tooltip:
-Household: within SHARP, a household is considered to include members of the immediate family (e.g. wife, husband, children, sister or brother) and other persons who are sharing the same shelter and share items such as food and resources.
-Household member: a household member is someone who has lived in the household at least six months, and at least three days in each week in those months. Also those persons who are not blood related (such as lodgers or agricultural laborers) are members of the household if they meet these qualifications.
-Crop Production: the actual harvested production from the field or orchard and gardens. Production includes the quantities sold in the market and those consumed or used by the producers (on-farm/household consumption).
-Animal Production: animals raised for the purpose of providing food or income (e.g. fibre, leather) for the members of the household.

components.title: 9. Pest management practices

components.label: In the last 12 months, did you take any actions to improve or preserve the quality of your soil?
components.tooltip: Soil quality: refers to how well the soil can fulfil its function (e.g. sustain plant and animal productivity, maintain or enhance water and air quality, support human health and habitation).

components.label: Which ones?

values.label: Agroforestry (trees grow in the fields), afforestation, forest protection
Liming (applying chalk, limestone, wood ashes and similar material to decrease soil acidity and improve soil activity)

components.tooltip:
-Slash and burn: method of clearing and burning forest or secondary vegetation for preparing agricultural and pastoral lands. Term is usually applied in the context of shifting cultivation.
-Fire break: any natural or constructed discontinuity in a fuelbed utilized to segregate, stop, and control the spread of fire or to provide a control line from which to suppress a fire; characterized by complete lack of combustibles down to mineral soil.
-Living fences: a field boundary formed by planting a line of closely spaced trees or shrubs.
-Vegetative strips: strips of land on the contour that left unploughed in order to form permanent, cross-slope barriers of naturally established grasses and herbs. They control soil erosion and prevent loss (through surface runoff) of fertilizers applied to the crop.
-Liming: the application of calcium and magnesium rich materials to soil to neutralise soil acidity and increase activity of soil bacteria.
-Rotational grazing: rotating  the area of land that animals/livestock use to feed (on a seasonal or other regular basis).
-Zero/Minimum tillage: it consists in reducing the breaking and turning over of the soil to the minimum when planting seeds.  This technique helps preserve and/or improve soil quality, by minimizing soil compaction and disturbances to beneficial soil micro-organisms, hence facilitating water infiltration and accumulation of soil organic matter.
-Mulching: it consists in laying a thin layer of vegetal cover on the ground to protect the soil from strong rainfall and excessive infiltration of water, and to enrich it with organic matter.
-Gullies: gullies are formed by an increase in surface run-off  (of watercourses).
-Gully Control/Rehabilitation: gully control is the process minimizing the gullies. Measures consists in (1) improving gully catchments to reduce and regulate the run-off rates; (2) diverting surface water above the gully area; (3) stabilizing gullies by structural measures and accompanying revegetation.

components.label: In the last 12 months, did you do anything to improve water conservation in your farm system and household?
components.tooltip:
-Water conservation: protecting natural water resources by placing limits on their use, waste, exploitation and pollution, as well as by reusing them through recovery or other treatment for the purpose of stemming their exhaustion.
-Pits: an excavated hole or cavity in the ground.
-Semi-circular bunds: semi-circular bunds are earth embankments in the shape of a semi-circle with the tips of the bunds on the contour. Semi-circular bunds, of varying dimensions, are used mainly for rangeland rehabilitation or fodder production.
-Stone bunds: contour stone bunds are used to slow down and filter runoff, thereby increasing infiltration and capturing sediment. The water and sediment harvested lead directly to improved crop performance.
-Water retention ditches: retention ditches are large ditches, designed to catch and retain all incoming runoff and hold it until it infiltrated into the ground. They are commonly used for trapping rainwater and for growing crops that have high water requirements
-Contour lines: contour bunds are a simplified form of microcatchments in which the bunds follow the contour, at close spacing, and by provision of small earth ties the system is divided into individual microcatchments.

components.tooltip:
-Nutrient runoff: when nutrient from commercial/farming/household activities reach freshwaters polluting it.
-Algal blooms: an algal bloom is a rapid increase or accumulation in the population of algae in freshwater or marine water systems.
-Activated carbon: charcoal which has been treated to remove hydrocarbons and to increase its adsorptive properties. It acts by condensing and holding a gas or solute onto its surface; thus inhibitory substances in nutrient medium may be adsorbed to charcoal included in the medium. Rooting factors such as phenolamines present as contaminants in charcoal may stimulate growth in vitro. Its addition to rooting medium may stimulate root initiation in some plant species. Activated charcoal may differ in origin and in composition.
-Chlorination of water: adding chlorine to an irrigation system to counteract clogging caused by organic materials such as algae and bacterial slime.
